was administered to the dying man, preparations made for the sacrament of unction, and in his house there was the bustle and thrill of suspense usual at such moments. Outside the house, beyond the gates, a group of undertakers, who hid when- ever a carriage drove up, waited in expectation of an important order for an expensive funer- al. The Military Governor of Moscow, who 
had been assiduous in sending aides-de-camp to inquire after the count's health, came him- self that evening to bid
